close_symbols: type of r_iov->iov[] elements (struct iovec or struct MHD_iovec)
explanation: memset: The target function calls memset(&msg, 0, sizeof(struct msghdr)). To verify MISRA rule compliance we must inspect the memset usage (destination pointer and size) to ensure it does not write beyond the object it targets. struct msghdr: Needed to know the exact layout/size of msg (and whether it contains flexible-array members or other non-standard layout) so sizeof(struct msghdr) is correct and memset(&msg, sizeof(...)) is safe. struct MHD_iovec_track_: Defines r_iov->cnt, r_iov->sent and r_iov->iov; needed to check all indexing and pointer arithmetic that could interact with any string.h usage (and to ensure msg.msg_iov is set to a valid iov pointer range). type of r_iov->iov[] elements (struct iovec or struct MHD_iovec): The element type defines iov_base and iov_len member types and sizes; required to ensure any pointer arithmetic (e.g. adjusting iov_base by track_sent) and any potential string operations on those buffers do not go out of bounds. MHD_iov_size_: The typedef used for iov_len arithmetic is required to check type conversions/underflows/overflows when reducing iov_len by track_sent (relevant to buffer bounds). _MHD_IOV_MAX: This macro can clamp items_to_send and thus affects how many iov entries are passed to sendmsg/writev; it is needed to reason about the indices/lengths passed and whether any subsequent memory accesses could be out of bounds. HAVE_SENDMSG: Controls the code path that contains the memset call (and how msg.msg_iov/msg.msg_iovlen are set). The analysis must know which path is compiled to see whether memset is actually used. pre_send_setopt and post_send_setopt: These callees are invoked immediately before/after the send calls. To fully determine whether any string.h functions are used (and whether those uses might violate the rule) we need their definitions. post_send_setopt calls MHD_DLOG (per call graph), so that callee chain must also be checked. MHD_DLOG: Included because post_send_setopt calls it; MHD_DLOG implementation might use string.h functions (sprintf/str* etc.), so include it to confirm there are no out-of-bounds string.h uses in the functions invoked by the target.
